chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.subtitle: About This Release
chapter.para: Release 1.5.90 is the first in a series of betas and release candidates for OpenNMS 1.6.
The code word for 1.5.90 is "tubeweasel"
Release 1.3.11 fixes a bug with events in 1.3.10.
The code word for 1.3.11 is "oopsy"

Release 1.3.10 is another bug fix/feature release. It contains a lot of bug fixes in preparation for the next stable release 1.6.0, as well as some changes to thresholding. In addition, OpenNMS now supports integration with the Hyperic HQ agent.
The code word for 1.3.10 is "caucus"
Release 1.3.9 is a small bug fix/feature release. A bug was fixed that could cause database connections to hang, and some small webUI enhancements were made.
The code word for 1.3.9 is "thanksgiving"
Release 1.3.8 is the next step on the road toward 1.8. Lots of bug fixes and some new features. The biggest news is initial support for running OpenNMS on Windows.
The code word for 1.3.8 is "redmond"

Release 1.3.7 is probably the best OpenNMS ever released. It removes the need for Tomcat, adds several new features including a SmokePing clone called StrafePing, and includes several performance enhancements.
The code word for 1.3.7 is "speedy"
Release 1.3.6 is the first release where the main OpenNMS application is pure Java. All of the C-based JNI code has been moved to packages outside of OpenNMS proper.
The code word for 1.3.6 is "blink"
Release 1.3.5 is a replacement for the aborted 1.3.4 release. It really fixes the notifications issue. In addition, some performance enhancements have been made to how data collection is started.
The code word for 1.3.5 is "expelliarmus"
Release 1.3.4 is a bugfix release against 1.3.3. Hey, release early and often. It fixes an issue with notifications triggered by trap events not working.
The code word for 1.3.4 is "ooops"

Release 1.3.3 is yet another major step toward OpenNMS 2.0. It should be considered much more stable than 1.3.2, so please disregard most of the scary warnings below, but if something should break we reserve the right to point one of them out. This release adds a new read-only Dashboard view using Google Web Toolkit, a new API for integrating with trouble ticketing systems (currently supporting Centric CRM), correlation rules and a number of other features. It also marks the start of our repackaging effort to move all C code out of the main OpenNMS branch, starting with the iplike postgresql function.
The code word for 1.3.3 is "e-peen"

Release 1.3.2 is a seriously huge upgrade to the OpenNMS application. It should be considered the pre-Alpha version of OpenNMS 2.0. It will most likely break your network, destroy your sanity, and cause you to put on sackcloth and wander the world as a beggar. That said, several people are using it in production, but please, do so at your own risk. Expect a hard upgrade path from OpenNMS 1.2, although fresh installs should be pretty simple. There are lots of really cool things in 1.3.2, so it is as least worth checking out on a development box. Please, don't use it in production unless you are experienced with OpenNMS and understand the risks.
The code word for 1.3.2 is "happynewyear"
Release 1.3.1 is a bug fix release to address an issue with a database connection leak. It also includes more NRPE client code and a new "examples" directory.

Release 1.3.0 is the first "development" release on the road to version 1.4.0. As a development release, it should be considered unstable for use in production environments, but you are encouraged to try it out. It contains a number of features such as a new alarms subsystem, automations via vacuumd, SNMP version 3 support, JMX data collection and more. Please, please note the "in progress" nature of this release, as large amounts of code have been rewritten. Unless you have a commercial support agreement or are just very brave, don't use it in production.
The code word for 1.3.0 is "wererabbit"

Release 1.2.5 is an important maintenance release for the stable branch of OpenNMS. It includes a major bug fix concerning possible polling deadlocks that can cause outages that are never resolved, as well as a large improvement to SNMP data collection speed and startup time.
The code word for 1.2.5 is "gromit".
Release 1.2.4 is yet another maintenance release for OpenNMS. It includes a few minor bug fixes, some new configurations, and a couple of small features.
The code word for 1.2.4 is "wootness".

Release 1.2.3 is another maintenance release in the OpenNMS stable branch. It addresses a polling issue that may cause polling to stop, as well as adding a final version of the poll-outages calendar. Also included are a number of new events and reports.
The code word for 1.2.3 is "sith".
Release 1.2.2 is 1.2.1 with one annoying webUI bug fixed.

Release 1.2.1 is a maintenance release in the OpenNMS stable branch. It contains a few bug fixes and several small features. "Stable" releases may contain new features, as long as it is determined that they pose a very small risk to current features. Usually, these features will add new functionality without modifying existing feature behavior.
The code word for 1.2.1 is "luckycharms".

Release 1.2.0 is the first stable, or production, release of OpenNMS in a long time. It is basically 1.1.5 with numerous bug fixes. With the release of 1.2.0, we will begin development on 1.3 - the next unstable release.
The code word for 1.2.0 is "valentine".

Release 1.1.5 is the second release candidate for 1.2. The biggest change involves poller code that has been nearly rewritten. This was in response to a new feature concerning notifications, and while we believe it to be very robust, it does represent a lot of code churn, so if you are using 1.1.4 in production, you may wish to wait a bit before upgrading to 1.1.5.

Also, with this version of the release notes, we are implementing a "code word". We try to make these notes useful, including tips on the majority of issues people will face while using the application, but still people tend to skip reading them. So now, if you want to post a 1.1.5-related question on the mailing lists, be sure to include the code word so people will know you have at least read this far into the release notes (grin).
The code word for 1.1.5 is "monsoon".
A quick summary of the new changes in 1.1.5, in no particular order:

listitem.para: New notification behavior - users can configure OpenNMS to send notices when an event is auto-acknowledged by notifd and they will only be sent to those people who received notice of the outage in the first place.
A number of new event definitions, including those from NetBotz, PATROL, Network Appliance and others.
Reorganized the datacollection-config.xml and snmp-graph.properties files to make them easier to manage. Also added a really cool CPU report for Net-SNMP agents.
KSC Reports can now be accessed from the main page.
Removed the need for a primary SNMP interface (i.e. the ability to map an ifIndex to an IP Address in the ipAddrTable. This will help with data collection from some devices.
Added database support for the ifAlias field.
Added a MATCH-ANY-UEI event. Useful in notifications, this event will cause a notification on any UEI. Now, for example, all events from a particular IP Address or Node can be sent as notifications.

chapter.para: There were also a large number of bug fixes and other small enhancements made to the code. Please test the heck out of this release and be sure to add issues to bugzilla (http://bugzilla.opennms.org) and we'll get 1.2.0 out as soon as possible.

Release 1.1.4 is the release candidate for 1.2 - the next stable branch of OpenNMS. It represents a tremendous amount of work in the areas of speed and performance. It incorporates many changes and bug fixes to make OpenNMS more Java centric - including a new installer. Current production users should note that this release contains a lot more changes to the underlying code than any release since 1.1.0, so if you are currently happy with 1.1.3 or an earlier version, you may want to wait a week or two before upgrading, or wait until 1.2.

OpenNMS 1.1.3 is a major milestone on the way to the next stable release, 1.2. It contains a number of improvements, especially under the covers, and is the first release created under the new build system.
OpenNMS 1.1.2 adds several new features and bug fixes. New features include a JDBC poller, a script-based poller and script-based event handler, as well as contributed support for a map.
OpenNMS 1.1.1 is the next step towards the production 1.2 release. It contains a number of new features and bug fixes.

OpenNMS 1.1 extends the work that was begun with 1.0 to make OpenNMS more powerful and easier to use. Almost all of the new functionality was suggested by current OpenNMS users. It is hoped that these improvements will prove useful, and will lead to even more suggestions on how to improve the product.
OpenNMS 1.0.2 is a maintenance release that fixes several code issues.
OpenNMS 1.0.1 is a maintenance release that fixes several code issues.
Please, let us know if you have any problems at all at the OpenNMS Bugzilla page.
